sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: While significant progress has been made in understanding the prebiotic formation of ribonucleotides (Becker et al., 2016; Benner et al., 2012; Kim et al., 2011; Powner et al., 2009) and characterizing ribozymes that might play a role in an RNA world (Attwater et al., 2018; Mutschler et al., 2015; Pressman et al., 2019; Tjhung et al., 2020), a convincing scenario bridging the gap between prebiotic chemistry and ribozyme-catalyzed replication is still missing. Here, we studied a scenario proposed by Zhou et al., 2021 (the ‘Virtual Circular Genome’, VCG) using theoretical and computational approaches. We analyzed the process whereby template-directed ligation replicates the genomic information that is collectively stored in the VCG oligomers. Our analysis revealed a trade-off between the fidelity and the yield of this process: At low concentration of VCG oligomers, most of the ligations produce oligomers that are too short to specify a unique locus on the genome, resulting in a low yield of replication (Figure 2B-C). At high VCG concentration, erroneous templated ligations cause sequence scrambling and consequently limit the fidelity of replication (Figure 2C-D). We considered two solutions to these issues: (i) a VCG pool composition that optimizes its replication behavior within the bounds of the fidelity-yield trade-off, and (ii) breaking the fidelity-yield trade-off given that error-prone ligations can be kinetically suppressed.

The first solution maximizes the yield of replication for fixed fidelity. In pools containing only monomers and VCG oligomers of a single length, replication efficiency can be maximized by increasing the length of VCG oligomers and decreasing their concentration (Figure 2F-G). This reduces the likelihood of error-prone templated ligation of long oligomers. When the pool contains VCG oligomers of multiple lengths, replication efficiency is typically governed by the longest oligomer in the pool (Figure 4D). Including dimers as feedstock for the replication increases the error fraction (Figure 5B-C), as dimers that bind to a template with a dangling end are prone to form an incorrect product (Figure 5D).

The second solution eliminates the error-prone templated ligation of two VCG oligomers by suppressing them kinetically, for example by assuring that only monomers are chemically activated. This enables both fidelity and yield to remain high at high VCG concentrations (Figure 6B), effectively breaking the fidelity-yield trade-off. Longer VCG oligomers are then more likely to be extended than shorter oligomers at equal concentration (Figure 6C). However, this is only true for pools with VCG oligomers of a single length — once multiple VCG oligomer lengths compete with each other, shorter oligomers can be more productive than longer ones (Figure 7B). This feature, which has also been observed experimentally (Ding et al., 2023), is caused by an asymmetry in the productive interaction between short and long oligomers (Figure 7C): While short oligomers can sequester longer oligomers as templates for their extension by a monomer, short oligomers are unlikely to serve as templates for longer oligomers (Figure 7D-E).

As we intended to study the pathways responsible for sequence scrambling and to explore possible mitigation strategies, we based our analysis on a coarse-grained model that neglects some experimental details. First, we assumed that a complex instantaneously dehybridizes if it contains a non-complementary base pair, whereas in reality, short duplexes can tolerate a limited number of mismatches (Todisco et al., 2024a). While such mismatches can facilitate incorrect hybridization and introduce additional replication errors, we expect this effect to be moderate: Mismatches preferentially occur near the ends of the hybridized region, where their destabilizing effect on binding is weakest (Todisco et al., 2024a). However, such terminal mismatches have also been shown to significantly reduce ligation rates (Rajamani et al., 2010 Leu et al., 2013), which in turn limits the likelihood of forming incorrect products.

Second, we simplified the hybridization dynamics by assuming that all oligomers bind to each other at equal rates, and that dehybridization rates are determined by the hybridization energy computed via a nearest-neighbor model. However, recent work has shown that hybridization to a gap flanked by two oligomers proceeds more slowly than binding to an unoccupied template. Moreover, the resulting nicked complexes (two oligomers hybridized adjacently on a template) are more stable than predicted by standard nearest-neighbor models due to enhanced stacking interactions at the nick site (Todisco et al., 2024b). While this added stability is not expected to affect overall replication efficiency of the VCG (since all productive complexes, correct or incorrect, contain a nick), it can impact the kinetics of the system. In particular, the extended lifetime of such complexes may challenge the adiabatic approximation used in much of our analysis, which assumes ligation is always slower than hybridization and dehybridization.

Third, we do not model the activation chemistry explicitly, but instead assume that all monomers (and, depending on the scenario, also oligomers) are always reactive. As a result, some activated intermediates that are known to form in experiments, such as imidazolium-bridged dinucleotides (Walton and Szostak, 2016), are not modeled. Nonetheless, we include aspects of activation chemistry in a coarse-grained manner. Specifically, to capture the experimentally observed difference in reactivity between monomer incorporation and templated ligation of oligomers under amino-imidazolium activation, we introduce two distinct ligation rate constants. With this approach, we describe the experimental setup well enough to qualitatively reproduce features observed in experiments, for example, the preferential extension of shorter oligomers by monomers in pools containing VCG oligomers of varying lengths (Ding et al., 2023).

The VCG scenario was proposed to close the gap between prebiotic chemistry and ribozyme-catalyzed replication. To this end, VCG pools need to be capable of replicating (parts of) ribozymes that play a role in the emergence of life. While there are cases of small ribozymes (Pressman et al., 2019) or ribozymes with small active sites (e.g. the Hammerhead ribozyme Scott, 2013), ribozymes obtained experimentally via in vitro evolution are often more than a hundred nucleotides long (Attwater et al., 2013; Johnston et al., 2001; Müller and Bartel, 2008; Wochner et al., 2011). Remarkably, our model suggests that the VCG scenario enables high-fidelity replication of long genomes, even in pools containing relatively short VCG oligomers. For a genome of length LG\begin{document}$L_{\rm G}$\end{document}, a sequence of at least LUmin=⌈ln⁡(2LG)ln⁡4⌉\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}= \Big\lceil \frac{\ln(2 L_{\rm G})}{\ln 4}\Big\rceil$\end{document} nucleotides is required to uniquely specify a position within the genome. If the oligomers in the pool exceed this length by about three nucleotides, accurate replication becomes feasible (Figure 2H). For example, genomes of length LG=1000nt\begin{document}$L_{\rm G}= 1000\,\text{nt}$\end{document} (LUmin=6,nt\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}= 6,\text{nt}$\end{document}) can be replicated in VCG pools containing 10nt\begin{document}$10\,\text{nt}$\end{document} oligomers. However, LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} equals LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document} only for a restricted set of genome sequences; more generally, LU>LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}\gt L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document}. In such cases, reliable replication requires correspondingly longer oligomers. While the precise margin between oligomer length and LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} depends on genome-specific features (particularly the motif distribution at sub-LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} scales), it typically amounts to only a few additional nucleotides (Appendix 2).

It is noteworthy that replication in the VCG scenario imposes a selection pressure on prebiotic genomes to reduce their unique motif length, LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}. A circular genome requiring many nucleotides to specify a unique locus (high LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}) replicates less efficiently than one with a shorter LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}, assuming all other properties of the VCG pool (particularly the oligomer length distribution) remain identical. This length distribution arises from the interplay between the chemical kinetics and molecular transport governed by the physical environment. For instance, templated ligation in an open system with continuous oligomer influx and outflux can produce a non-monotonic length distribution, with a concentration peak at a characteristic oligomer length Lc\begin{document}$L_{\rm c}$\end{document}, determined by the interplay between dehybridization and outflux (Rosenberger et al., 2021). Through this emergent length scale, the environment shapes replication in the VCG scenario. If the environment facilitates long oligomers (Lc>LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm c}\gt L_{\rm U}$\end{document}), replication proceeds efficiently. Conversely, in environments with a small Lc\begin{document}$L_{\rm c}$\end{document}, repeating motifs longer than Lc\begin{document}$L_{\rm c}$\end{document} are selected against. In such cases, mutational errors may replace long repeated motifs with functionally equivalent sequences composed of shorter unique motifs, thereby increasing replication efficiency.

Given the broad range of prebiotically plausible non-equilibrium environments (Ianeselli et al., 2023), it is reasonable to expect that some environments provide the required conditions for efficient replication. The constraints formulated in this work can help to guide the search for self-replicating oligomer pools, in the vast space of possible concentration profiles and non-equilibrium environments.

sec.title: Constructing circular genomes
sec.p: In the Virtual Circular Genome (VCG) scenario, genomes are encoded in a pool of oligomers. The encoded genomes are assumed to be circular sequences of length LG\begin{document}$L_{\rm G}$\end{document}, containing both the original sequence and its reverse complement. Each genome is characterized by two fundamental length scales that reflect different aspects of motif distribution along the sequence. The minimal unique motif length, LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}, is defined as the shortest subsequence length for which all motifs of length L≥LU\begin{document}$L \geq L_{\rm U}$\end{document} appear at most once in the genome. In contrast, the exhaustive coverage length, LE\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}$\end{document}, denotes the largest motif length for which all 4LE\begin{document}$4^{L_{\rm E}}$\end{document} possible motifs are present within the genome. Since only 2LG\begin{document}$2 L_{\rm G}$\end{document} distinct motifs can be encoded in a genome (including its complement), LE\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}$\end{document} cannot exceedLEmax=⌊ln⁡(2LG)ln⁡4⌋.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \,L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}= \Big\lfloor \frac{\ln(2 L_{\rm G})}{\ln 4}\Big\rfloor.$$\end{document}

Similarly, for a motif to be uniquely addressable on the genome, its length must be at leastLUmin=⌈ln⁡(2LG)ln⁡4⌉.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}= \Big\lceil \frac{\ln(2 L_{\rm G})}{\ln 4}\Big\rceil.$$\end{document}

We note that LEmax\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document} and LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document} are essentially the same length scale (differing by at most one nucleotide).

The characteristic length scales LE\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}$\end{document} and LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} impose constraints on how motifs are distributed. For example, when L=LU\begin{document}$L = L_{\rm U}$\end{document}, all motifs of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} must appear at most once, while at least one motif of length L−1\begin{document}$L-1$\end{document} must occur more than once. To quantify the motif distribution, we introduce the motif entropy,S(L)=−∑i=14Lfilnfi,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S(L)=-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{4^L}f_{\,i}\, {\rm ln}\, f_{\,i},$$\end{document}

where fi\begin{document}$f_{i}$\end{document} denotes the relative frequency of motif i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} across the genome and its reverse complement. Motif entropy ranges from zero (a homogeneous sequence with only one motif) to a maximum value that depends on the subsequence length,Smax(L)={LifL≤LG,ln⁡(2LG)ln⁡4ifL>LG.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\,S^{\mathrm{max}}(L) = \begin{cases}L&\text{if}\, L \leq L_{\rm G}\,, \\ \frac{\ln (2 L_{\rm G})}{\ln 4}&\text{if}\, L \gt L_{\rm G}\, .\end{cases}\end{array}$$\end{document}

For motif length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} to qualify as the unique motif length LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}, its entropy must be maximal, S(L)=Smax(L)\begin{document}$S(L)=S^{\mathrm{max}}(L)$\end{document}, while S(L−1)\begin{document}$S(L-1)$\end{document} must be smaller than its respective maximum, S(L−1)<Smax(L−1)\begin{document}$S(L-1) \lt S^{\mathrm{max}}(L-1)$\end{document}.

The correspondence between characteristic length scales and motif entropies provides a way to construct genome sequences with specified motif characteristics. By treating the entropy function as an effective ‘Hamiltonian’ H\begin{document}$\mathcal{H}$\end{document}, we can generate genome sequences through Metropolis–Hastings sampling. In our implementation, each update step in the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm involves either a single-nucleotide mutation or a cut-and-paste operation that relocates a segment of the genome to a new position (the cut-and-paste operation is 10 times more likely than the single nucleotide mutation). The acceptance criterion follows the standard Metropolis rule: modifications that reduce the Hamiltonian are always accepted, while increases in ‘energy’ are accepted with probability exp⁡[−β(Eold−Enew)]\begin{document}$\exp\left[ - \beta (E_{\mathrm{old}}- E_{\mathrm{new}}) \right]$\end{document}. Here, β−1\begin{document}$\beta^{-1}$\end{document} is an effective temperature chosen to be small compared to the typical energy to ensure convergence to the minimum. Simulations are either run until a predefined entropy target is reached or until the energy converges to a plateau.

To generate genomes with LE=LEmax\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}= L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document} and LU=LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}= L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document}, we minimize the HamiltonianH=−S(LE)−S(LU)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal H=-S(L_{\rm E})-S(L_{\rm U})$$\end{document}

Starting from a random sequence, we perform 10,000 Metropolis–Hastings steps at an inverse temperature β=10−5\begin{document}$\beta = 10^{-5}$\end{document} to construct genome sequences of lengths LG=16nt\begin{document}$L_{\rm G}=16\,\text{nt}$\end{document} (listed in Results) and LG=64nt\begin{document}$L_{\rm G}= 64\,\text{nt}$\end{document} (listed in Supplementary file 1). To explore genomes with LE<LEmax\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}\lt L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document} and LU>LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}\gt L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document}, we initialize the algorithm from the maximally diverse genomes (LE=LEmax\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}= L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document}, LU=LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}= L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document}) and then reduce entropy across the range LE<L<LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}\ltL\ltL_{\rm U}$\end{document}. This is done by minimizing the HamiltonianH=∑L=LELUS(L),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{H}= \sum_{L = L_{\rm E}}^{L_{\rm U}}S(L),$$\end{document}

via two different sampling protocols. In the first protocol, the simulation is terminated as soon as the genome reaches the desired values of LE\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}$\end{document} and LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document}. The resulting motif distributions on the intermediate length scales (LE<L<LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}\lt L \lt L_{\rm U}$\end{document}) remain close to uniform, with only minor biases sufficient to enforce the length-scale constraints. In the second protocol, entropy minimization continues beyond the point at which the target values are achieved, leading to more strongly biased motif distributions on intermediate length scales. These construction strategies allow us to systematically tune genome complexity and motif structure, enabling controlled investigations of how the characteristic length scales influence replication dynamics (see Appendix 2 for details).

sec.title: Computing replication observables based on the kinetic simulation
sec.p: We simulate the dynamics of VCG pools using a kinetic simulation that is based on the Gillespie algorithm. In the simulation, oligomers can hybridize to each other to form complexes or dehybridize from an existing complex. Moreover, two oligomers can undergo templated ligation if they are hybridized adjacent to each other on a third oligomer. At each time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document}, the state of the system is determined by a list of all single-stranded oligomers and complexes as well as their respective copy number. We refer to the state of the system at the time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} as the ensemble of compounds Et\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}_{t}$\end{document}. Given the copy numbers, the rates ri\begin{document}$r_{i}$\end{document} of all possible chemical reactions i∈I\begin{document}$i \in \mathcal{I}$\end{document} can be computed. To evolve the system in time, we need to perform two steps: (i) We sample the waiting time until the next reaction, τ\begin{document}$\tau$\end{document}, from an exponential distribution with mean (∑i∈Iri)−1\begin{document}$(\sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}}r_{i})^{-1}$\end{document}, and update the simulation time, t→t+τ\begin{document}$t \rightarrow t + \tau$\end{document}. (ii) We pick which reaction to perform by sampling from a categorical distribution. Here, the probability to pick reaction i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} equals ri/(∑i∈Iri)\begin{document}$r_{i}/ (\sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}}r_{i})$\end{document}. The copy numbers are updated according to the sampled reaction, yielding Et+τ\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}_{t+\tau}$\end{document}. Steps (i) and (ii) are repeated until the simulation time t\begin{document}$t$\end{document} reaches the desired final time, tfinal\begin{document}$t_{\text{final}}$\end{document}. A more detailed explanation of the kinetic simulation is presented in Göppel et al., 2022; Rosenberger et al., 2021.

Our goal is to compute observables characterizing replication in the VCG scenario based on the full kinetic simulation. In the following derivation, we focus on one particular observable (yield) for clarity. The results for other observables are stated directly, as their derivations follow analogously. Recall the definition of the yield introduced in the Results section,y=#nucleotidesincorporatedinVCGoligomersuntilτlig#incorporatednucleotidesuntilτlig.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y = \frac{\rm{\# \,nucleotides\, incorporated \,in \,VCG \,oligomers \,until}\, \tau_{\text{lig}}}{\rm\,{\# incorporated \,nucleotides \,until}\, \tau_{\text{lig}}}.$$\end{document}

As we are interested in the initial replication performance of the VCG, we compute the yield based on the ligation events that take place until the characteristic timescale of ligations τlig=klig−1≈1012 t0\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{lig}}= k_{\text{lig}}^{-1}\approx 10^{12}~ t_{0}$\end{document}. In principle, we would like to compute the yield based on the templated ligation events that we observe in the simulation. Unfortunately, for reasonable system parameters, it is impossible to simulate the system long enough to observe sufficiently many ligation events to compute y\begin{document}$y$\end{document} to reasonable accuracy. For example, for a VCG pool containing monomers at a total concentration of cFtot =0.1mM\begin{document}$c_{\mathrm{F}}^{\text {tot }}=0.1 \,\mathrm{mM}$\end{document} and VCG oligomers of length L=8nt\begin{document}$L = 8\,{\rm nt}$\end{document} at a total concentration of cVtot=1μM\begin{document}$c_{\mathrm{V}}^{\rm {tot }}=1\,\mathrm{\text \muM}$\end{document}, it would take about 1700 hr of simulation time to reach t=5⋅1012t0\begin{document}$t = 5 \cdot 10^{12}\,t_{0}$\end{document} (Figure 8). Multiple such runs would be needed to estimate the mean and the variance of the observables of interest, rendering this approach unfeasible.

The energy contribution per matching nearest-neighbor block is set to γ=−2.5 kBT\begin{document}$\gamma = -2.5~k_{\mathrm{B}}\text{T}$\end{document}. The volume of the system is varied, and the time evolution is simulated until t=5.0⋅107t0\begin{document}$t = 5.0 \cdot 10^{7}t_{0}$\end{document}. The runtime of the simulation scales linearly with the volume of the system.

sec.p: Instead, we compute the replication observables based on the copy number of complexes that could potentially perform a templated ligation, that is complexes in which two strands are hybridized adjacent to each other, such that they could form a covalent bond. We can show analytically that the number of productive complexes is a good approximation for the number of incorporated nucleotides: The number of incorporated nucleotides can be computed as the integral over the ligation flux, weighted by the number of nucleotides that are added in each templated ligation reaction,(#incorporatednucleotidesuntil τlig)=∫0τligdt ∑C∈EtN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \,({\rm \#\, incorporated\, nucleotides \,until}~ \tau_{\text{lig}}) = \int_{0}^{\tau_\text{lig}}\mathrm{d}t~\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}_t} N(\text {C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}})\,\mathbb {1}(\text{C allows templated ligation}).$$\end{document}

Here, N(C)\begin{document}$N(\text{C})$\end{document} denotes the copy number of the complex C in the pool Et\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}_{t}$\end{document}. Le,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{e,1}}$\end{document} and Le,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{e,2}}$\end{document} denote the lengths of the oligomers that undergo ligation, and 1\begin{document}$\mathbb{1}$\end{document} is an indicator function which enforces that only complexes in a ligation-competent configuration contribute to the reaction flux. As only a few ligation events are expected to happen until τlig\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{lig}}$\end{document}, it is reasonable to assume that the ensembles Et\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}_{t}$\end{document} do not change significantly during t∈[0,τlig]\begin{document}$t \in [0, \tau_{\text{lig}}]$\end{document}. Therefore, the integration over time may be interpreted as a multiplication by τlig\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{lig}}$\end{document},(6)(#incorporatednucleotidesuntil τlig)≈τlig⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation)⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle ({\rm \#\, incorporated\, nucleotides\, until}~ \tau_{\text{lig}})\approx \tau_{\text{lig}}\Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}(\text{C allows templated ligation}) \Bigr\gt,$$\end{document}

where ⟨…⟩\begin{document}$\langle \dots \rangle$\end{document} denotes the average over realizations of the ensembles Et\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}_{t}$\end{document} within the time interval t∈[τeq,τlig]\begin{document}$t \in [\tau_{\text{eq}}, \tau_{\text{lig}}]$\end{document}. This average corresponds to the average number of complexes in a ligation-competent configuration. Note that, at this point, we made the additional assumption that no templated ligations are taking place between [0,τeq]\begin{document}$[0, \tau_{\text{eq}}]$\end{document}. This assumption is reasonable, as (i) the equilibration process is very short compared to the characteristic timescale of ligation, and (ii) the number of complexes that might allow for templated ligation during equilibration is lower than in equilibrium (we start the simulation with an ensemble of single-stranded oligomers). Both aspects imply that the rate of templated ligation is negligible during the interval [0,τeq]\begin{document}$[0, \tau_{\rm eq}]$\end{document}.

In order to compute the average over different realizations of ensembles E\begin{document}$\mathcal{E}$\end{document} (as required in Equation 6), we need to sample a set of uncorrelated ensembles that have reached the hybridization equilibrium, which can be done using the full kinetic simulation. The simulation starts with a pool containing only single-stranded oligomers and reaches the (de)hybridization equilibrium after a time τeq\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{eq}}$\end{document}. We identify this timescale of equilibration by fitting an exponential function to the total hybridization energy of all complexes in the system, ΔGtot\begin{document}$\Delta G_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} (Figure 9A). In the set of ensembles used to evaluate the average in Equation 6, we only include ensembles for time t>τeq\begin{document}$t \gt \tau_{\text{eq}}$\end{document} to ensure that the ensembles have reached (de)hybridization equilibrium. To ensure that the ensembles are uncorrelated, we require that the time between two ensembles that contribute to the average is at least τcorr\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{corr}}$\end{document}. The correlation time, τcorr\begin{document}$\tau_{\text{corr}}$\end{document}, is determined via an exponential fit to the autocorrelation function of ΔGtot\begin{document}$\Delta G_{\text{tot}}$\end{document} (Figure 9B). Besides computing the expectation value (Equation 6), we are also interested in the ‘uncertainty’ of this expectation value, that is in the standard deviation of the sample mean σ⟨X⟩\begin{document}$\sigma_{\langle X \rangle}$\end{document}. (We use X\begin{document}$X$\end{document} as a short-hand notation for ∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(Callowstemplatedligation)\begin{document}$\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}{\rm (C\, allows\, templated\, ligation)}$\end{document}). The standard deviation of the sample mean, σ⟨X⟩\begin{document}$\sigma_{\langle X \rangle}$\end{document}, is related to the standard deviation of X\begin{document}$X$\end{document}, σX\begin{document}$\sigma_{X}$\end{document}, by the number of samples, σ⟨X⟩=(Ns)−1/2σX\begin{document}$\sigma_{\langle X \rangle}= (N_{s})^{-1/2}\sigma_{X}$\end{document}. Moreover, based on the van-Kampen system size expansion, we expect the standard deviation of X\begin{document}$X$\end{document} to be proportional to V−1/2\begin{document}$V^{-1/2}$\end{document}, such that σ⟨X⟩∝(NsV)−1/2\begin{document}$\sigma_{\langle X \rangle}\propto (N_{s}V)^{-1/2}$\end{document}.

The horizontal dashed line shows the total hybridization energy expected in (de)hybridization equilibrium according to the coarse-grained adiabatic approach (Methods). In both panels, we show simulation data obtained for a VCG pool containing monomers and VCG oligomers with a concentration of cFtot=0.1mM\begin{document}$c^{\mathrm{tot}}_{\mathrm{F}}= 0.1\,{\rm mM}$\end{document} as well as oligomers of length L=8 nt\begin{document}$L=8~\text{nt}$\end{document} with a concentration of cVtot=1μM\begin{document}$c^{\mathrm{tot}}_{\mathrm{V}}= 1\,\rm{\mu M}$\end{document}.

sec.p: Using Equation 6 (as well as an analogous expression for the number of nucleotides that are incorporated in VCG oligomers), the yield can be expressed asy=⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(Callowstemplatedligation)1(Le,1+Le,2≥LU)⟩⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(Callowstemplatedligation)⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y = \frac{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}},\, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}{\rm (\text{C}\, allows\, templated\, ligation)}\,\mathbb {1}(L_{\text{e,1}}\,+\,L_{\text{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}) \Bigr> }{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}{\rm(\text{C}\, allows\, templated\, ligation)} \Bigr\gt }.$$\end{document}

The additional condition 1(Le,1+Le,2≥LU)\begin{document}$\mathbb {1}(L_{\text{e,1}}+L_{\text{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U})$\end{document} in the numerator ensures that the product oligomer is long enough to be counted as a VCG oligomer, that is at least LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} nucleotides long. Analogously, the expression for the fidelity of replication readsf=⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation)1(Le,1+Le,2≥LU)1(product correct)⟩⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation)1(Le,1+Le,2≥LU)⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \,f = \frac{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}(\text{C allows templated ligation})\,\mathbb {1}(L_{\text{e,1}}+L_{\text{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U})\,\mathbb {1}(\text{product correct})\Bigr> }{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N( \text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}(\text {C allows templated ligation})\,\mathbb {1}(L_{\text{e,1}}+L_{\text{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}) \Bigr\gt }.$$\end{document}

Multiplying fidelity and yield results in the efficiency of replication,η=⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(Callowstemplatedligation)1(Le,1+Le,2≥LU)1(product correct)⟩⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(Callowstemplatedligation)⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta = \frac{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}},\, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}( {\rm C\, allows\, templated\, ligation)}\,\mathbb {1}(L_{\text{e,1}}\,+\,L_{\text{e,2}}\,\geq\, L_{\rm U})\,\mathbb {1}(\text{product correct})\Bigr> }{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}({\rm C\, allows\, templated\, ligation)} \Bigr\gt }.$$\end{document}

The ligation share of a particular type of templated ligation s(type)\begin{document}$s(\text{type})$\end{document}, that is, the relative contribution of this templated-ligation type to the nucleotide extension flux, can be represented in a similar form as the other observables,s(type)=⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation of given type)⟩⟨∑C∈EN(C)min(Le,1,Le,2)1(C allows templated ligation)⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle s(\text{type}) = \frac{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}(\text{C allows templated ligation of given type)}\Bigr> }{ \Bigl\lt\,\sum_{\text{C} \in \mathcal{E}}N(\text{C})\,\text{min}(L_{\text{e,1}}, L_{\text{e,2}}) \mathbb {1}(\text{C allows templated ligation)} \Bigr\gt }.$$\end{document}

As all observables are expressed as the ratio of two expectation values, Z=⟨X⟩/⟨Y⟩\begin{document}$\mathcal{Z}= \langle X \rangle / \langle Y \rangle$\end{document}, we can compute the uncertainty of the observables via Gaussian error propagation,σZ=σ⟨X⟩2⟨Y⟩2+⟨X⟩2 σ⟨Y⟩2⟨Y⟩4−2⟨X⟩ σ⟨X⟩,⟨Y⟩2⟨Y⟩3 .\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sigma_{\mathcal{Z}}= \sqrt{ \frac{\sigma^{2}_{\langle X \rangle}}{\langle Y \rangle^{2}}+ \frac{\langle X \rangle^{2}~\sigma^{2}_{\langle Y \rangle}}{\langle Y \rangle^{4}}- \frac{2 \langle X \rangle~\sigma^{2}_{\langle X \rangle, \langle Y \rangle}}{\langle Y \rangle^{3}}~ }.$$\end{document}

Since the variances, σ⟨X⟩2\begin{document}$\sigma^{2}_{\langle X \rangle}$\end{document} and σ⟨Y⟩2\begin{document}$\sigma^{2}_{\langle Y \rangle}$\end{document}, as well as the covariance, σ⟨X⟩,⟨Y⟩2\begin{document}$\sigma^{2}_{\langle X \rangle, \langle Y \rangle}$\end{document}, are proportional to (NsV)−1\begin{document}$(N_{s}V)^{-1}$\end{document}, the standard deviation of the observable mean, σZ\begin{document}$\sigma_{Z}$\end{document}, scales with the inverse square root of the number of samples and the system volume, that is σZ∝(NsV)−1/2\begin{document}$\sigma_{Z}\propto (N_{s}V)^{-1/2}$\end{document}. Therefore, the variance of the computed observable can be reduced by either increasing the system volume or increasing the number of samples used for averaging. Both approaches incur the same computational cost: (i) Increasing the number of samples, Ns\begin{document}$N_{s}$\end{document}, requires running the simulation for a longer duration, with the additional runtime scaling linearly with the number of samples. (ii) Similarly, the additional runtime needed due to increased system volume, V\begin{document}$V$\end{document}, also scales linearly with V\begin{document}$V$\end{document} (Figure 8). One update step in the simulation always takes roughly the same amount of runtime, but the change in simulation time per update step depends on the total rate of all reactions in the system. The total rate is dominated by the association reactions, and their rate is proportional to the volume. Therefore, the change in simulation time per update step is proportional to V−1\begin{document}$V^{-1}$\end{document}. The runtime, which is necessary to reach the same simulation time in a system with volume V\begin{document}$V$\end{document} as in a system with volume 1, is a factor of V\begin{document}$V$\end{document} longer in the larger system. With this in mind, it makes no difference whether the variance is reduced by increasing the volume or the number of samples. For practical reasons (post-processing of the simulations is less memory- and time-consuming), we opt to choose a moderate number of samples, but slightly higher system volumes to compute the observables of interest. The simulation parameters (length of oligomers, concentrations, hybridization energy, volume, number of samples, characteristic timescales) used to obtain the results presented in Figure 2 are summarized in Table 1.

sec.title: Coarse-grained representation of complexes in the adiabatic approach
sec.p: To characterize the replication performance of VCG pools across a broad range of system parameters, we developed an adiabatic approach that enables faster computation of replication observables than full kinetic simulations. In this method, we compute the equilibrium concentrations of complexes in productive configurations under the assumption that templated ligation is much slower than (de)hybridization. The approach relies on a coarse-grained representation of the oligomers in the pool, which we introduce in this section.

sec.title: Single strands
sec.p: In the coarse-grained description, oligomers of identical length are assumed to have equal concentration, irrespective of their sequence. This assumption is justified for two reasons: (i) We initialize the VCG pool without sequence bias, that is all oligomers compatible with the genome sequence are included at equal concentration. (ii) Hybridization energy in our simplified energy model (and therefore also the stability of complexes) only depends on the length of the hybridization site, not on its sequence, such that oligomers of equal length have similar probabilities of being free or bound in complexes. Under this assumption, each coarse-grained oligomer is uniquely identified by its length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}, and it represents a group of oligomers with C(L)\begin{document}$\mathfrak{C}(L)$\end{document} distinct sequences. We refer to the number C(L)\begin{document}$\mathfrak{C}(L)$\end{document} as the combinatorial multiplicity of the coarse-grained oligomer. The value of C(L)\begin{document}$\mathfrak{C}(L)$\end{document} depends on the choice of the encoded genome. We assume that by construction, all possible oligomer sequences of length L≤LEmax\begin{document}$L \leq L_{\rm E}^{\text{max}}$\end{document} are included in the genome (see Methods for the definition of LEmax\begin{document}$L_{\rm E}^{\mathrm{max}}$\end{document} and LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}^{\mathrm{min}}$\end{document}). For L≥LUmin=LEmax+1\begin{document}$L \geq L_{\rm U}^{\text{min}}= L_{\rm E}^{\text{max}}+1$\end{document}, only a subset of all possible 4L\begin{document}$4^{L}$\end{document} sequences is included, but no sequence is repeated multiple times across the genome. Therefore, the combinatorial multiplicity equalsC(L)={4Lif L<LUmin,2LGif L≥LUmin.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathfrak{C}(L) = \left\{\begin{array}{ll}4^L & \text{if } L \lt L_{\rm U}^{\min}, \\2L_{\rm G} & \text{if } L\geq L_{\rm U}^{\min}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

sec.title: Duplexes
sec.p: Two strands can form a duplex by hybridizing to each other. We refer to the bottom oligomer as ‘Crick’ strand C and to the top oligomer as ‘Watson’ strand W. A duplex is uniquely characterized by the lengths of the oligomers, LC\begin{document}$L_{\text{C}}$\end{document} and LW\begin{document}$L_{\text{W}}$\end{document}, as well as their relative alignment (Figure 10A). The alignment index i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} denotes the position of the Watson strand with respect to the Crick strand. As there needs to be at least one nucleotide of overlap between the strands for a duplex to exist, the alignment index needs to be in the interval i∈[−(LW−1),LC−1]\begin{document}$i \in [-(L_{\text{W}}-1), L_{\text{C}}-1]$\end{document}. Using the alignment index, we can also determine if the duplex has a left (or right) dangling end. The corresponding indicator variables are called dl\begin{document}$d_{l}$\end{document} (or dr\begin{document}$d_{r}$\end{document}),dl={1ifi=0,0otherwise,dr={1ifi+LW=LC,0otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\,d_{l}= \begin{cases}1\quad \text{if}\, i = 0, \\ 0\quad \text{otherwise},\end{cases}\, d_{r}= \begin{cases}1\quad \quad \text{if}\, i + L_{\text{W}}= L_{\text{C}}, \\ 0\quad \quad \text{otherwise}.\end{cases}\end{array}$$\end{document}

The relative position of the strands is characterized by the alignment index i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}; for the depicted duplex, i=−2\begin{document}$i = -2$\end{document}. The length of the hybridization region is called Lo\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}$\end{document}. (B) A ternary complex contains three strands. By convention, we denote the two strands that are on the same ‘side’' of the complex as W1 and W2, and the complementary strand as C. sec.p: Moreover, the length of the hybridization region Lo\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}$\end{document} can be computed viaLo=min(LC,i+LW)−max(i,0).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{o}}= \text{min}(L_{\text{C}}, i+L_{\text{W}}) - \text{max}(i,0).$$\end{document}

The hybridization energy of the duplex depends on the length of the hybridization region as well as on the existence/absence of dangling ends. For a hybridization site of length Lo\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}$\end{document}, there are Lo−1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}-1$\end{document} nearest-neighbor energy blocks each of which contributes γ\begin{document}$\gamma$\end{document} to the energy. Moreover, each dangling end contributes γ2\begin{document}$\frac{\gamma}{2}$\end{document} to the energy,E=γ(Lo−1)+γ2(dl+dr).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \gamma (L_{\text{o}}-1) + \frac{\gamma}{2}(d_{l}+ d_{r}).$$\end{document}

To compute the combinatorial multiplicity for a duplex with fixed LC\begin{document}$L_{\text{C}}$\end{document}, LW\begin{document}$L_{\text{W}}$\end{document} and alignment index i\begin{document}$i$\end{document}, we need to multiply the combinatorial multiplicity of the Crick strand by the number of possible hybridization partners. We assume that a hybridization partner is possible if its sequence is perfectly complementary to the lower strand within the hybridization region, whereas hybridization partners with mismatches are not accounted for. This is sensible as long as the energetic penalty for mismatches in the full kinetic simulation is sufficiently large to suppress mismatches. The number of possible hybridization partners is determined by the length of the overlap region Lo\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}$\end{document}: If Lo≥LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\text{o}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}$\end{document}, the pool contains only one oligomer sequence that can act as hybridization partner by construction of the genome. For shorter hybridization regions, multiple hybridization partners might be possible. Their number is set by the combinatorial multiplicity of the Watson oligomer divided by the combinatorial multiplicity of the hybridization region,C(LC,LW,i)={C(LC)C(LW)4Lo if Lo<LUmin,C(LC)if Lo≥LUmin.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}}, L_{\text{W}}, i) = \begin{cases}\frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_\text{C}) \mathfrak{C}(L_\text{W})}{4^{L_\text{o}}}~ ~&\text{if}~L_{\text{o}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}, \\ \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}})&\text{if}~ L_{\text{o}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}.\end{cases}\end{array}$$\end{document}

To avoid double-counting, we only account for complexes in which the Crick strand is at least as long as the Watson strand, LC≥LW\begin{document}$L_{\text{C}}\geq L_{\text{W}}$\end{document}, and multiply C(LW,LC,i)\begin{document}$\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W}}, L_{\text{C}}, i)$\end{document} by 1/2\begin{document}$1/2$\end{document} if LW=LC\begin{document}$L_{\text{W}}= L_{\text{C}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Ternary complexes
sec.p: Ternary complexes, that is complexes comprised of three strands, are uniquely characterized by the length of the three oligomers, LC,LW,1,LW,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{C}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}$\end{document}, as well as their respective alignment (Figure 10B). The alignment index i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} denotes the position of strand W1 relative to strand C. Analogously, j\begin{document}$j$\end{document} denotes the relative position of W2 relative to oligomer C. Two strands that are hybridized to each other need to have a hybridization region of at least one nucleotide. Moreover, the strands W1 and W2 must not occupy the same position on the template strand C. Taking both requirements together, the alignment indices fall within the intervals,i∈[−(LW,1−1), LC−LW,1−1], and j∈[i+LW,1, LC−1].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i \in [-(L_{\text{W,1}}-1),~L_{\text{C}}-L_{\text{W,1}}-1],~~~\text{and}~~~ j \in [i+L_{\text{W,1}},~L_{\text{C}}-1].$$\end{document}

A ternary complex may have a dangling end not only on its left or right end, but also in the gap between strands W1 and W2. Three boolean variables are necessary to denote the presence/absence of the respective dangling ends,dl={0if i=0,1otherwise,dm={0if i+LW,1=j,1otherwise,dr={0if j+LW,2=LC,1otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle d_l = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 0 & \text{if } i = 0, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}, \end{array} \right. \quad d_m = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 0 & \text{if } i + L_{\rm W,1} = j, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}, \end{array} \right. \quad d_r = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 0 & \text{if } j + L_{\rm W,2} = L_{\rm C}, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.$$\end{document}

The length of the two hybridization regions is given byLo,1=i+LW,1−max(i,0), and Lo,2=min(j+LW,2,LC)−j.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{o,1}}= i+L_{\text{W,1}}- \text{max}(i,0),~~~\text{and}~~~ L_{\text{o,2}}= \text{min}(j+L_{\text{W,2}},L_{\text{C}}) - j.$$\end{document}

The hybridization energy depends on the length of the overlap regions as well as on the existence of dangling ends: As in the duplex, each overlap region of length Lo,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}$\end{document} (or Lo,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,2}}$\end{document}) comprises Lo,1−1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}-1$\end{document} (or Lo,2−1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,2}}-1$\end{document}) nearest neighbor blocks, each of which contributes γ\begin{document}$\gamma$\end{document} to the total energy. Moreover, every dangling end contributes γ/2\begin{document}$\gamma/2$\end{document}. Note that the presence of a gap between strands W1 and W2, that is dm=1\begin{document}$d_{m}= 1$\end{document}, implies that there are two dangling ends, one for W1 and another for W2. Gaps in between two complexes contribute γ/2\begin{document}$\gamma/2$\end{document} per each dangling end, adding up to γ\begin{document}$\gamma$\end{document}. If there is no gap between the strands, that is dm=0\begin{document}$d_{m}= 0$\end{document}, there are no dangling end contributions, but a new full nearest neighbor block emerges, which contributes γ\begin{document}$\gamma$\end{document} to the energy. Therefore, the total energy reads,E=γ(Lo,1+Lo,2−2)+γ2(dl+dr+2dm)+γ(1−dm).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \gamma (L_{\text{o,1}}+ L_{\text{o,2}}- 2) + \frac{\gamma}{2}(d_{l}+ d_{r}+ 2 d_{m}) + \gamma (1 - d_{m}).$$\end{document}

The combinatorial multiplicity of a ternary complex is computed in the same way as for the duplex: The combinatorial multiplicity of the strand C is multiplied by the number of possible hybridization partners W1 and W2. Again, the number of possible partners is set by the length of the hybridization regions,C(LC,LW,1,LW,2,i,j)=C(LC)×[C(LW,1)4Lo,11(Lo,1<LUmin)+1(Lo,1≥LUmin)]×[C(LW,2)4Lo,21(Lo,2<LUmin)+1(Lo,2≥LUmin)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, i, j) = \mathfrak{C}(L_{\rm C}) \hspace{-1.5ex} & \times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,1}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\ltL_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min} \right) \right]\\ & \times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,2}})}{4^{L_\text{o,2}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min} \right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min} \right) \right].\end{array}$$\end{document}

We use 1\begin{document}$\mathbb{1}$\end{document} to denote the indicator function which returns 1 in case the condition in the bracket is fulfilled and zero otherwise. As all ternary complexes are asymmetric, there is no need to introduce a symmetry correction factor.

sec.title: Quaternary complexes
sec.p: The largest complexes to be accounted for in our coarse-grained adiabatic approach are quaternary complexes, that is complexes comprised of four strands. We need to distinguish three types of such complexes: (i) 3-1 quaternary complexes, (ii) left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complexes, and (iii) right-tilted 2-2 quaternary complexes. In 3-1 quaternary complexes, three Watson strands are hybridized to one Crick strand (Figure 11), whereas in 2-2 quaternary complexes, two Watson strands are hybridized to two Crick strands (Figure 12 and Figure 13).

caption.title: Schematic representation of a 3-1 quaternary complex.
caption.p: Three strands (referred to as Watson strands W1, W2, and W3) hybridize to a single template strand (Crick strand C). The positions relative to the left end of the C strand are given by the alignment indices i,j\begin{document}$i, j$\end{document}, and k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}; here, i=−2,j=2,k=5\begin{document}$i = -2, j = 2, k = 5$\end{document}. The length of the overlap regions is denoted as Lo,1,Lo,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}, L_{\text{o,2}}$\end{document}, and Lo,3\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,3}}$\end{document}.

caption.title: Schematic representation of a left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex.
caption.p: (A) Two Watson strands (W1 and W2) are hybridized to two Crick strands (C1 and C2). Both Watson strands are hybridized to the left Crick strand C1, whereas only W2 is hybridized to the right Crick strand C2. The alignment indices i,j\begin{document}$i, j$\end{document} and k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} denote the position of the strands relative to the left end of C1; here, i=−2\begin{document}$i = -2$\end{document}, j=3\begin{document}$j = 3$\end{document} and k=6\begin{document}$k = 6$\end{document}. The length of the hybridization regions is called Lo,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}$\end{document}, Lo,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,2}}$\end{document}, and Lo,3\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,3}}$\end{document}. (B) Rotating the schematic representation of a left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex by 180∘\begin{document}$180^{\circ}$\end{document} produces an alternative representation of the same complex, which is again a left-tilted 2-2 complex. The panel depicts the rotated complex representation (variables with superscript ‘rot’) as well as the non-rotated representation (variables without superscript). There is a unique linear mapping between non-rotated and rotated representation, for example C2 after rotation always corresponds to W1 before rotation.

caption.title: Schematic representation of a right-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex.
caption.p: (A) Two Watson strands (W1 and W2) are hybridized to two Crick strands (C1 and C2). Unlike in the left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex, both Watson strands are hybridized to the right Crick strand C2, whereas only W1 is hybridized to the left Crick strand C1. The alignment indices i,j\begin{document}$i, j$\end{document}, and k\begin{document}$k$\end{document} denote the positions of the strands relative to C1; here, i=1\begin{document}$i = 1$\end{document}, k=3\begin{document}$k = 3$\end{document}, and j=6\begin{document}$j = 6$\end{document}. The length of the overlap regions is called Lo,1,Lo,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}, L_{\text{o,2}}$\end{document} and Lo,3\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,3}}$\end{document}. (B) Rotating the schematic representation of a right-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex by 180∘\begin{document}$180^{\circ}$\end{document} produces an alternative representation of the same complex, which is again a right-tilted 2–2 complex. The panel depicts the rotated complex representation (variables with superscript ‘rot’) as well as the non-rotated representation (variables without superscript). There is a unique linear mapping between non-rotated and rotated representation, for example C2 after rotation always corresponds to W1 before rotation. The mapping is identical for left- and right-tilted 2–2 quaternary complexes.

sec.title: 3-1 Quaternary complexes
sec.p: Figure 11 depicts a typical 3-1 quaternary complex. Such a complex is uniquely characterized by the length of its oligomers, LC,LW,1,LW,2,LW,3\begin{document}$L_{\text{C}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, L_{\text{W,3}}$\end{document}, as well as their relative position to each other denoted by the alignment indices i,j\begin{document}$i, j$\end{document}, and k\begin{document}$k$\end{document}. All positions within the ternary complex are measured relative to the left end of the C strand. Any W strand needs to have at least one nucleotide of overlap with the C strand, but two W strands must never occupy the same position on the C strand. Consequently, the alignment indices fall within the intervals,i∈[−(LW,1−1),LC−LW,1−LW,2−1], j∈[i+LW,1,LC−LW,2−1], and k∈[j+LW,2,LC−1].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i \in [-(L_{\text{W,1}}-1), L_{\text{C}}-L_{\text{W,1}}-L_{\text{W,2}}-1],~~~~ j \in [i+L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{C}}-L_{\text{W,2}}-1],~~~\text{and}~~~ k \in [j+L_{\text{W,2}}, L_{\text{C}}-1].$$\end{document}

There are two dangling ends (left and right) and potentially two gaps between the W strands: one gap between W1 and W2 and another one between W2 and W3. The following boolean variables indicate the presence/absence of the respective dangling ends,dl={0if i=0,1otherwise, dm1={0if i+LW,1=j,1otherwise,dm2={0if i+LW,2=k,1otherwise, dr={0if k+LW,3=LC,1otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle &d_{l}= \begin{cases}0&\text{if}~ i=0, \\ 1&\text{otherwise,}\end{cases}~~~&&d_{m1}= \begin{cases}0&\text{if}~ i+L_{\text{W,1}}=j, \\ 1&\text{otherwise},\end{cases}\\&d_{m2}= \begin{cases}0&\text{if}~ i+L_{\text{W,2}}=k, \\ 1&\text{otherwise},\end{cases}~~&&d_{r}= \begin{cases}0&\text{if}~ k+L_{\text{W,3}}=L_{\text{C}}, \\ 1&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} $$\end{document}

The length of the hybridization regions is given byLo,1=i+LW,1−max(i,0), Lo,2=LW,2, and Lo,3=min(LC,k+LW,3)−k.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{o,1}}= i + L_{\text{W,1}}- \text{max}(i,0),~~~~ L_{\text{o,2}}= L_{\text{W,2}},~~~\text{and}~~~ L_{\text{o,3}}= \text{min}(L_{\text{C}}, k+L_{\text{W,3}}) - k.$$\end{document}

Following the same reasoning as in the case of ternary complexes, the energy equalsE=γ(Lo,1+Lo,2+Lo,3−3)+γ(1−dm1)+γ(1−dm2)+γ2(dl+dr+2dm1+2dm2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \gamma (L_{\text{o,1}}+ L_{\text{o,2}}+ L_{\text{o,3}}- 3) + \gamma (1 - d_{m1}) + \gamma (1 - d_{m2}) + \frac{\gamma}{2}(d_{l}+ d_{r}+ 2 d_{m1}+ 2 d_{m2}).$$\end{document}

Similarly, the combinatorial multiplicity of 3-1 quaternary complexes is constructed using the same reasoning as in the case of ternary complexes,C(LC,LW,1,LW,2,LW,3,i,j,k)=C(LC)×[C(LW,1)4Lo,11(Lo,1<LUmin)+1(Lo,1≥LUmin)]×[C(LW,2)4Lo,21(Lo,2<LUmin)+1(Lo,2≥LUmin)]×[C(LW,3)4Lo,31(Lo,3<LUmin)+1(Lo,3≥LUmin)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, L_{\text{W,3}}, i, j, k)= \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}})\hspace{-1.5ex}&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,1}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,2}})}{4^{L_\text{o,2}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,3}})}{4^{L_\text{o,3}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right].\end{array}$$\end{document}
As 3-1 quaternary complexes are not symmetric under rotation, no symmetry correction of the combinatorial multiplicity is necessary.

sec.title: Left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complexes
sec.p: A 2-2 quaternary complex is comprised of two C strands and two W strands. We call a 2-2 complex left-tilted if strand W1 is connected to strand W2 via strand C1 (Figure 12A). The lengths of the oligomers are called LW,1,LW,2,LC,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, L_{\text{C,1}}$\end{document}, and LC,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{C,2}}$\end{document}. The positions of the strands relative to each other are governed by the alignment indices. All positions are measured relative to the position of the left end of strand C1. The alignment indices may take on the following values,i∈[−(LW,1−1),LC,1−LW,1−1], j∈[i+LW,1,LC,1], and k∈[LC,2,j+LW,2−1].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i \in [-(L_{\text{W,1}}-1), L_{\text{C},1}-L_{\text{W,1}}-1],~~~~ j \in [i+L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{C,1}}],~~~\text{and}~~~ k \in [L_{\text{C},2}, j+L_{\text{W,2}}-1].$$\end{document}

The complex can have dangling ends on the right and on the left end of the complex; the presence of these dangling ends is indicated by the boolean variables dl\begin{document}$d_{l}$\end{document} and dr\begin{document}$d_{r}$\end{document}. Moreover, two gaps are possible: There might be a gap between strands W1 and W2, or a gap between C1 and C2. The respective boolean variables readdl={0if i=0,1otherwise,dm1={0if i+LW,1=j,1otherwise,dm2={0if LC,1=k,1otherwise,dr={0if j+LW,2=k+LC,2,1otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle &d_l = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } i = 0, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise},\end{cases} \quad &&d_{m1} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } i + L_{\rm W,1} = j, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}, \end{cases} \\[10pt] &d_{m2} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } L_{\rm C,1} = k, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}, \end{cases} \quad && d_r = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } j + L_{\rm W,2} = k + L_{\rm C,2}, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise}. \end{cases} $$\end{document}

We refer to the hybridization region of strand W1 and C1 as overlap region 1, to the hybridization region of strand W2 and C1 as overlap region 2 and to the hybridization region of strand W2 and C2 as overlap region 3. The length of these hybridization regions is computed viaLo,1=i+LW,1−max(i,0), Lo,2=LC,1−j, and Lo,3=min(j+LW,2,k+LC,2)−k.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{o,1}}= i + L_{\text{W,1}}- \text{max}(i,0),~~~~ L_{\text{o,2}}= L_{\text{C,1}}- j,~~~\text{and}~~~ L_{\text{o,3}}= \text{min}(j+L_{\text{W,2}}, k+L_{\text{C,2}}) - k.$$\end{document}

Given the length of the hybridization region as well as the presence/absence of dangling ends, we can compute the hybridization energy,E=γ(Lo,1+Lo,2+Lo,3−3)+γ(1−dm1)+γ(1−dm2)+γ2(dl+dr+2dm1+2dm2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \gamma (L_{\text{o,1}}+ L_{\text{o,2}}+ L_{\text{o,3}}- 3) + \gamma (1 - d_{m1}) + \gamma (1 - d_{m2}) + \frac{\gamma}{2}(d_{l}+ d_{r}+ 2 d_{m1}+ 2 d_{m2}).$$\end{document}

The combinatorial multiplicity of a left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex is constructed using the same reasoning as in the case of a 3-1 complex,C(LC,1,LC,2,LW,1,LW,2,i,j,k)=C(LC)×[C(LW,1)4Lo,11(Lo,1<LUmin)+1(Lo,1≥LUmin)]×[C(LW,2)4Lo,21(Lo,2<LUmin)+1(Lo,2≥LUmin)]×[C(LC,1)4Lo,31(Lo,3<LUmin)+1(Lo,3≥LUmin)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C,1}}, L_{\text{C,2}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, i, j, k)= \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}}) \hspace{-1.5ex} &\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,1}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,2}})}{4^{L_\text{o,2}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,3}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right].\end{array}$$\end{document}

To prevent double-counting the same quaternary complex, we include either the complex or its rotated representation in the container of possible complexes, but not both. If the complex is symmetric under rotation, we multiply the combinatorial multiplicity by 1/2\begin{document}$1/2$\end{document}. Given a left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex (LC,1,LC,2,LW,1,LW,2,i,j,k)\begin{document}$(L_{\text{C,1}}, L_{\text{C,2}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, i, j, k)$\end{document}, we can compute the corresponding rotated complex (LC,1rot,LC,2rot,LW,1rot,LW,2rot,irot,jrot,rot)\begin{document}$(L_{\text{C,1}}^{\text{rot}}, L_{\text{C,2}}^{\text{rot}}, L_{\text{W,1}}^{\text{rot}}, L_{\text{W,2}}^{\text{rot}}, i^{\text{rot}}, j^{\text{rot}}, ^{\text{rot}})$\end{document} by applying a linear map. The mapping of the oligomer lengths is illustrated in Figure 12B. We see that strand C2 after rotation corresponds to strand W1 before rotation, implying that LC,2rot=LW,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{C,2}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{W,1}}$\end{document}. The same reasoning can be applied to all strands leading to the map,LC,1rot=LW,2, LC,2rot=LW,1, LW,1rot=LC,2, and LW,2rot=LC,1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{C,1}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{W,2}},~~~~ L_{\text{C,2}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{W,1}},~~~~ L_{\text{W,1}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{C,2}},~~~\text{and}~~~ L_{\text{W,2}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{C,1}}.$$\end{document}

In order to compute the map of the alignment indices under rotation, we need to express the relative positions of the strands with respect to the position of strand C1 after rotation, which corresponded to W2 before rotation. For example, |irot|\begin{document}$|i^{\text{rot}}|$\end{document} corresponds to the number of nucleotides by which strand C2 (before rotation) protrudes beyond strand W2 (before rotation). Expressed in terms of variables before rotation, this distance may be written as k+LC,2−jLW,2\begin{document}$k+L_{\text{C,2}}-jL_{\text{W,2}}$\end{document}. Analogous relations can be derived for all alignment indices,irot=j−k+LW,2−LC,2, jrot=j+LW,2−LC,1, and krot=j−i+LW,1−LW,2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i^{\text{rot}}= j - k + L_{\text{W,2}}- L_{\text{C,2}},~~~~ j^{\text{rot}}= j + L_{\text{W,2}}- L_{\text{C,1}},~~~\text{and}~~~ k^{\text{rot}}= j - i + L_{\text{W,1}}- L_{\text{W,2}}.$$\end{document}

sec.title: Right-tilted 2-2 quaternary complexes
sec.p: A 2-2 quaternary complex is called right-tilted if strand W1 is connected to strand W2 via strand C2 (Figure 13). As in the case of the left-tilted 2-2 complex, the oligomer lengths are again called LW,1,LW,2,LC,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, L_{\text{C,1}}$\end{document} and LC,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{C,2}}$\end{document}, but the values of the alignment indices that are possible for the right-tilted quaternary complex differ from the ones of the left-tilted complex,i∈[LC,1−LW,1−1,LC,1−1], j∈[LC,1,i+LW,1−1], and k∈[i+LW,1,k+LC,2−1].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle i \in [L_{\text{C,1}}-L_{\text{W,1}}-1, L_{\text{C,1}}-1],~~~~ j \in [L_{\text{C,1}}, i+L_{\text{W,1}}-1],~~~\text{and}~~~ k \in [i+L_{\text{W,1}}, k+L_{\text{C,2}}-1].$$\end{document}

Note that the range of i\begin{document}$i$\end{document} is chosen such that at least one nucleotide of strand W1 always extends to the right beyond the end of strand C1, allowing for a hybridization region between strand C2 and W1. The boolean variables denoting the presence/absence of dangling ends readdl={0if i=0,1otherwise,dm1={0if i+LW,1=j,1otherwise,dm2={0if LC,1=k,1otherwise,dr={0if j+LW,2=k+LC,2,1otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle &d_l = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } i = 0, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise,} \end{cases} &&d_{m1} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } i + L_{\rm W,1} = j, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise,} \end{cases} \\ &d_{m2} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } L_{\rm C,1} = k, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise,} \end{cases} &&d_r = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } j + L_{\rm W,2} = k + L_{\rm C,2}, \\ 1 & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases} $$\end{document}

The length of the overlap regions is given byLo,1=LC,1−max(i,0), Lo,2=i+LW,1−k, and Lo,3=min(k+LC,2,j+LW,2)−j.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L_{\text{o,1}}= L_{\text{C,1}}- \text{max}(i,0),~~~~ L_{\text{o,2}}= i+L_{\text{W,1}}-k,~~~\text{and}~~~ L_{\text{o,3}}= \text{min}(k+L_{\text{C,2}}, j+L_{\text{W,2}}) - j.$$\end{document}

Like in the case of left-tilted 2-2 quaternary complexes, the total hybridization energy is computed viaE=γ(Lo,1+Lo,2+Lo,3−3)+γ(1−dm1)+γ(1−dm2)+γ2(dl+dr+2dm1+2dm2),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \gamma (L_{\text{o,1}}+ L_{\text{o,2}}+ L_{\text{o,3}}- 3) + \gamma (1 - d_{m1}) + \gamma (1 - d_{m2}) + \frac{\gamma}{2}(d_{l}+ d_{r}+ 2 d_{m1}+ 2 d_{m2}),$$\end{document}

and the combinatorial multiplicity viaC(LC,1,LC,2,LW,1,LW,2,i,j,k)=C(LC)×[C(LW,1)4Lo,11(Lo,1<LUmin)+1(Lo,1≥LUmin)]×[C(LW,2)4Lo,21(Lo,2<LUmin)+1(Lo,2≥LUmin)]×[C(LC,1)4Lo,31(Lo,3<LUmin)+1(Lo,3≥LUmin)].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C,1}}, L_{\text{C,2}}, L_{\text{W,1}}, L_{\text{W,2}}, i, j, k)= \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C}})\hspace{-1.5ex}&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,1}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,1}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{W,2}})}{4^{L_\text{o,2}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right]\\&\times\left[ \frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{C,1}})}{4^{L_\text{o,3}}}\mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\lt L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) + \mathbb {1}\left(L_{\text{o,3}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}\right) \right].\end{array}$$\end{document}

We include either the quaternary complex or its rotated representation in the list of possible complexes to avoid double-counting. Moreover, the combinatorial multiplicity is divided by 2 if the complex is symmetric under rotation. It turns out that the rotation map for the right-tilted 2-2 quaternary complex is identical to the one of the left-tilted 2-2 complex,LC,1rot=LW,2, LC,2rot=LW,1, LW,1rot=LC,2, LW,2rot=LC,1,irot=j−k+LW,2−LC,2, jrot=j+LW,2−LC,1, and krot=j−i+LW,1−LW,2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}&L_{\text{C,1}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{W,2}},~~~~ L_{\text{C,2}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{W,1}},~~~~ L_{\text{W,1}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{C,2}},~~~~ L_{\text{W,2}}^{\text{rot}}= L_{\text{C,1}}, \\&i^{\text{rot}}= j - k + L_{\text{W,2}}- L_{\text{C,2}},~~~~ j^{\text{rot}}= j + L_{\text{W,2}}- L_{\text{C,1}},~~~\text{and}~~~ k^{\text{rot}}= j - i + L_{\text{W,1}}- L_{\text{W,2}}.\end{array}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Numerical solution of the (De)hybridization equilibrium in the adiabatic approach
sec.p: Based on the list of complexes constructed in the previous section, we can compute the equilibrium concentration of strands and complexes reached in the (de)hybridization equilibrium. In the following, we denote the concentration of a coarse-grained oligomer with length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} as c(L)\begin{document}$c(L)$\end{document}, and the concentration of an oligomer with length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} and known sequence as cs(L)\begin{document}$c_{s}(L)$\end{document}. Recall that we assumed that all sequences of a given length that are compatible with the circular genome are equally likely in the pool. Thus, the concentration of the coarse-grained oligomer and the concentration of an oligomer with specified sequence are related by the combinatorial multiplicity,c(L)=C(L)cs(L).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c(L) = \mathfrak{C}(L)c_{s}(L).$$\end{document}

In order to compute the concentration of a complex based on the concentration of single strands, we make use of the law of mass action. The concentration of a specific sequence realization of a complex is computed as the product of concentrations of the strands forming the complex divided by the dissociation constant Kd\begin{document}$K_{\rm d}$\end{document},cs(L→,i→)=1Kd(L→,i→)∏jcs(Lj).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c_{s}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,) = \frac{1}{K_{\rm d}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)}\prod_{j}c_{s}(L_{j}).$$\end{document}

Here, L→\begin{document}$\vec{L}$\end{document} is the vector denoting the lengths of the strands comprising the complex, and i→\begin{document}$\vec{i}$\end{document} are the alignment indices. The dissociation constant is set by the hybridization energy, ΔG\begin{document}$\Delta G$\end{document}, of the complex,Kd(L→,i→)=(c∘)n−1exp⁡(βΔG),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \, K_{\rm d}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,) = (c^{\circ})^{n-1}\exp(\beta \Delta G),$$\end{document}

where c∘=1M\begin{document}$c^{\circ}=1 \mathrm{M}$\end{document} is the standard concentration. Just as in the case of single strands, the concentration of the sequence-independent coarse-grained complex is related to the concentration of a complex with specific sequence realization via the combinatorial prefactor,c(L→,i→)=C(L→,i→)cs(L→,i→).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,) = \mathfrak{C}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)\,c_{s}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,).$$\end{document}

It can be useful to combine the combinatorial multiplicity and the dissociation constant into a single effective association constant,Ka(L→,i→)=C(L→,i→)Kd(L→,i→).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{K}_{\rm a}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,) = \frac{\mathfrak{C}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)}{K_{\rm d}(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,)}.$$\end{document}

Note that the effective association constant including the combinatorial multiplicity is denoted by Ka\begin{document}$\mathcal{K}_{\rm a}$\end{document} (in curly font), while the association constant without combinatorial multiplicity is denoted Ka=Kd−1\begin{document}$K_{\rm a}= K_{\rm d}^{-1}$\end{document} (in regular font).

In the adiabatic approach, we study the behavior of the system on timescales that are long enough for the system to reach the (de)hybridization equilibrium, but too short for templated ligation events to take place. Therefore, the length of the oligomers is expected not to change throughout the equilibration process, and we need to introduce a separate mass conservation law for each coarse-grained oligomer, that is each oligomer length, that is included in the pool. For each length, the concentration of single-stranded coarse-grained oligomers of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} and the concentration of coarse-grained oligomers of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} bound in a complex need to add up to their total concentration c(L)\begin{document}$c(L)$\end{document} set by the initial condition,ceq(L)+∑(L→,i→)|∃js.t.L→j=Lceq(L→,i→)=ctot(L).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(L\right)+ \sum_{(\vec{L}, \vec{i})\,|\,\exists\,j\,\text{s.t.}\,\vec{L}_j = L}c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,\right)= c^{\mathrm{tot}}(L).$$\end{document}

In this equation, (L→,i→)|∃js.t.L→j=L\begin{document}$(\vec{L}, \vec{i})\,|\,\exists\,j\,\text{s.t.}\,\vec{L}_{j}= L$\end{document} denotes the summation over all complexes that contain at least one strand of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document}. Note that we referred to the total concentration of oligomers of length L\begin{document}$L$\end{document} as c(L)\begin{document}$c(L)$\end{document} in the main text, but for clarity, we use ctot(L)\begin{document}$c^{\mathrm{tot}}(L)$\end{document} in the following.

Combining the mass conservation requirement with the mass action law gives a set of coupled polynomial equations. The number of equations equals the number of distinct oligomer lengths included in the pool. The polynomial equations are of degree 4, as quaternary complexes are the largest complexes to be accounted for and their concentrations equal the product of the four strands comprising the complex. We determine the equilibrium concentrations by finding the root of this set of fourth-degree polynomial equations using the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm.

sec.title: Computing replication observables based on the adiabatic approach
sec.p: As we are not modeling templated ligation events explicitly in the adiabatic approach, we compute replication observables based on the equilibrium concentration of complexes that are in a configuration which allows for a templated ligation reaction to happen. Templated ligations are possible if two strands in the complex are adjacent to each other, that is there is no gap in between two oligomers that are hybridized to the same template strand (Figure 14). Recall that the absence of a gap between two oligomers in the complex implies that the dangling end indicator variable dm=0\begin{document}$d_{m}= 0$\end{document}. The length of the product strand P is equal to the sum of the lengths of the two educt strands E1 and E2, Lp=Le,1+Le,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{p}}= L_{\text{e,1}}+ L_{\text{e,2}}$\end{document}. We can use the information about the length of the product strand to compute the yield of replication. By definition, the yield equals the fraction of nucleotides used to form VCG oligomers, that is strands that are at least LU\begin{document}$L_{\rm U}$\end{document} long,(7)y=#nucleotidesincorporatedinVCGoligomers#incorporatednucleotides.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y = \frac{{\rm\#\, nucleotides\, incorporated\, in\, VCG\, oligomers}}{{\rm \#\, incorporated\, nucleotides}}.$$\end{document}

caption.title: Schematic representation of a complex that allows templated ligation.
caption.p: The strands E1 and E2 are adjacent to each other, such that a covalent bond can form between their ends. The length of the product strand, Lp\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{p}}$\end{document}, is set by the length of the educt strands, Le,1\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{e,1}}$\end{document} and Le,2\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{e,2}}$\end{document}. The likelihood for the complex to form a product oligomer whose sequence is compatible with the true circular genome, pcorr\begin{document}$p_{\text{corr}}$\end{document}, is determined by the length of the educts and the length of their hybridization region with the template. The parts of the complex shown with hatching do not affect pcorr\begin{document}$p_{\text{corr}}$\end{document}.

sec.p: We can express this quantity in terms of the equilibrium concentration of complexes facilitating templated ligation,y=∑(L→,i→)|(dm=0∧Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin) min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→)∑(L→,i→)|dm=0 min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle y = \frac{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,)\,|\,(d_m = 0\,\wedge\,L_\mathrm{e,1}+L_\mathrm{e,2}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min})}~ \text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i})\,|\,d_m = 0}~ \text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}.$$\end{document}

(L→,i→)|(dm=0∧Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin)\begin{document}$(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,)\,|\,(d_{m}= 0\,\wedge\,L_{\mathrm{e,1}}+L_{\mathrm{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min})$\end{document} denotes the summation over all complexes, in which (i) the strands E1 and E2 are adjacent to each other, that is dm=0\begin{document}$d_{m}= 0$\end{document}, and (ii) the length of the product Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{e,1}}+ L_{\mathrm{e,2}}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min}$\end{document}. We multiply the equilibrium concentration by the length of the shorter educt strand to account for the number of incorporated nucleotides in line with the definition of the yield (Equation 7).

In order to compute the fidelity of replication, we need to distinguish between product oligomer sequences that are compatible with the genomes (correct sequences) and sequences that are incompatible with the genome (false sequences). As we do not know about the details of the sequences due to the coarse-grained representation of the complexes, we need to invoke a combinatorial argument to determine the fraction of correct products. To this end, we compare the number of product sequences that might be produced in a complex of given oligomer lengths and alignment indices to the number of correct products associated with the same complex configuration. The combinatorial multiplicity of the products that could be produced by a complex of given configuration is set by the combinatorial multiplicity of the possible templates, C(Lo,1+Lo,2)\begin{document}$\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,1}}+L_{\text{o,2}})$\end{document}, multiplied by the multiplicity of the educt strands hybridizing to the template with given lengths of the hybridization regions, Lo,1\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,1}}$\end{document} and Lo,2\begin{document}$L_{\text{o,2}}$\end{document},C(possible products)=C(Lo,1+Lo,2)C(Le,1)C(Lo,1)C(Le,2)C(Lo,2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathfrak{C}(\text{possible products})= \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,1}}+L_{\text{o,2}})\frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}})}{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,1}})}\frac{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\mathrm{e,2}})}{\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,2}})}.$$\end{document}

The multiplicity of correct products equals the combinatorial multiplicity of strands that have the same length as the product,C(correct products)=C(Le,1+Le,2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathfrak{C}(\text{correct products})= \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{e,1}}+L_{\text{e,2}}).$$\end{document}

This implies that the probability for a complex of given shape (L→,i→)\begin{document}$(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)$\end{document} to form a correct product is given bypcorr(L→,i→)=C(correct products)C(possible products)=C(Le,1+Le,2)C(Lo,1)C(Lo,2)C(Lo,1+Lo,2)C(Le,1)C(Le,2).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p_{\text{corr}}(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,) = \frac{\mathfrak{C}(\text{correct products})}{\mathfrak{C}(\text{possible products})}= \frac{ \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{e,1}}+L_{\text{e,2}})\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,1}})\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,2}}) }{ \mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{o,1}}+L_{\text{o,2}})\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{e,1}})\,\mathfrak{C}(L_{\text{e,2}})}.$$\end{document}

Using this probability, we can compute the fidelity of replication,f=∑(L→,i→)|(dm=0∧Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin) pcorr(L→,i→)min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→)∑(L→,i→)|(dm=0∧Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin) min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f = \frac{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i})\,|\,(d_m = 0\,\wedge\,L_\mathrm{e,1}+L_\mathrm{e,2}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min})}~ p_{\text{corr}}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)\,\text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i})\,|\,(d_m = 0\,\wedge\,L_\mathrm{e,1}+L_\mathrm{e,2}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min})}~ \text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}$$\end{document}

as well as the replication efficiency,η=∑(L→,i→)|(dm=0∧Le,1+Le,2≥LUmin) pcorr(L→,i→)min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→)∑(L→,i→)|dm=0 min(Le,1,Le,2)ceq(L→,i→).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta = \frac{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i})\,|\,(d_m = 0\,\wedge\,L_\mathrm{e,1}+L_\mathrm{e,2}\geq L_{\rm U}^{\rm min})}~ p_{\text{corr}}(\vec{L}, \vec{i}\,)\,\text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}{\sum_{(\vec{L},\vec{i})\,|\,d_m = 0}~ \text{min}(L_{\mathrm{e,1}}, L_{\mathrm{e,2}})\,c^{\mathrm{eq}}\left(\vec{L},\vec{i}\,\right)}.$$\end{document}

sec.title: Scaling of replication efficiency with oligomer length in single-length VCG pools
sec.p: We consider a pool containing monomers and VCG oligomers of a single length. As the feedstock only contains monomers, the total monomer concentration and the total feedstock concentration are identical, cFtot=ctot(1)\begin{document}$c^{\mathrm{tot}}_{\mathrm{F}}= c^{\mathrm{tot}}(1)$\end{document}. Similarly, the total VCG concentration equals the total concentration of oligomers of length LV\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{V}}$\end{document}, cVtot=ctot(LV)\begin{document}$c^{\mathrm{tot}}_{\mathrm{V}}= c^{\mathrm{tot}}(L_{\mathrm{V}})$\end{document}. In systems of this type, the replication efficiency can be expressed asη=cF+V,c+LV cV+V,ccF+F+cF+V+LV cV+V,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta = \frac{c_{\mathrm{F+V,c}}+ L_{\mathrm{V}}~ c_{\mathrm{V+V,c}}}{c_{\mathrm{F+F}}+ c_{\mathrm{F+V}}+ L_{\mathrm{V}}~ c_{\mathrm{V+V}}},$$\end{document}

where the concentrations denote the equilibrium concentration of all complexes facilitating the indicated type of templated ligation. Note that we do not include F+F ligations (i.e. dimerizations) in the numerator as they do not contribute to the yield. Moreover, the V+V ligations are multiplied by the length of the oligomers LV\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{V}}$\end{document}, as each V+V extends an existing oligomer by LV\begin{document}$L_{\mathrm{V}}$\end{document} nucleotides.
